text: My mother-in-law was a school teacher for 43 years. She taught Special Ed. It takes a special human being to do that. She went into the Drop program and worked an additional 4 years in the school system, but not in Special Ed too much. At 69 she had to retire, and at age 70 the symptoms started. About a year later the family decided it was best to put her in an assisted living home. The family had to transfer all her assets to her children. She received $3,400 a month in retirement which the Assisted Living Home took to take care of her. We were fortunate in that the home was just a quarter mile from my house and my wife is a registered nurse who was very close to her mom. She visited her everyday, sometimes twice in a day if she was off from work. This was good in many ways, including the fact that the home knew she was close by and could pop in any time. Over a 3 year period I watched my mother-in-law deteriorate, and I watched my wife in pain dealing with it, and all I could do was hug her and tell her I much I loved her. There were 6 other brothers and sisters and only one of the brothers really visited her often. I told my wife how she could hold her head up high and know in her heart that she took care of her mom. One day during her last year of life I went with my wife to visit her. She wasn't talking much then, but out of no where she looks at my wife from her bed and tells her with tears rolling down her face. "You are a really good daughter. I had to leave the room because the tears were flowing, and because I knew that she knew her time on this earth was coming to an end. My wife was  with her when she passed at the young age of 74. I will always remember her as one of the best human beings I was lucky enough to have in my life. I just wish I would have told her so.

context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: How This Native Educator Is Keeping A Tribal Language Alive
context_meta.summary: On the Omaha Native American reservation in northeastern Nebraska, one educator is working hard to keep the tribal language alive by helping kids to learn it in school. Vida Woodhull Stabler is the director of the Omaha (or “Umonhon” in the tribe’s language) culture center at Umonhon Nation Public Schools in Macy, Nebraska. Alongside other elders in the community, she has helped to developed a curriculum and lesson plans for Umonhon language classes, as well as other ways to infuse students’ day-to-day school experience with culturally relevant learnings, such as tribal songs and dance.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Two Mothers Open Up About What Happens When Kids With Autism Grow Up
context_meta.summary: People today are very aware of the challenges of raising a child with autism. From job opportunities to housing to social interactions, there are many aspects to worry about. Elaine Hall and Sue Patton know this all too well. Sue lives in a small town in Indiana called Pendleton.

context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Houston Will Get Hit With Another Harvey. Now's The Time For It To Get Ready.
context_meta.summary: As Houston begins the long rebuilding process after Hurricane Harvey, it has an opportunity to transform itself into a city ready and resilient in the face of climate change and the possibility of more extreme weather events. While it’s difficult to know whether climate change is directly responsible for a particular hurricane, some scientists say it will make storms worse and more frequent, and their aftermaths more deadly. The devastation that Harvey wreaked underscores the importance of urgent action.

context_meta.title: Introducing I'm Still Here: A New HuffPost Podcast About Survival
context_meta.summary: In America, a local tragedy can spark a national conversation. For a new podcast series called I’m Still Here, we’ll visit communities whose tales of adversity have put them on the map and we’ll explore what “survival” in America really looks like. What does it mean to survive when a black teenager in your community has been senselessly gunned down by a cop in your hometown?

context_meta.title: Nebraska’s Nonpartisan, Unicameral Legislature Is A Model Of Deliberative Democracy
context_meta.summary: The Nebraska state legislature, which meets in Lincoln, is the only unicameral state legislature in the US and was specifically designed in the 1930s with multiple features to foster deliberative democracy by enhancing transparency and downplaying party politics.
